name: HarvardPublicHealth
tweet: There is a lot of information out there about the #coronavirus - Harvard Chan epidemiologist @mlipsitch and @ccdd_hsph have a breakdown of what scientists know right now, and how they know it.

name: HarvardPublicHealth
tweet: How severe is the #coronavirus? It‚Äôs hard to estimate ‚Äì severe cases (that lead to hospitalization or death) are the most likely to be reported. People may be infected with the virus and have few or no symptoms.

name: HarvardPublicHealth
tweet: How will we contain the #coronavirus outbreak? Since scientists don‚Äôt yet know how often infected people might transmit the virus before showing symptoms, it‚Äôs uncertain which approaches will be most effective ‚Äì but vaccine candidates are already in development.

name: HarvardPublicHealth
tweet: How long has the #coronavirus been around? Rapid genomic sequencing helps scientists estimate that the virus was first introduced in Nov or Dec 2019. As the epidemic spreads, it will help scientists monitor which cases are imported, and which are transmitted locally.

name: HarvardPublicHealth
tweet: How many people are infected? Scientists looked at how many people travel each day from Wuhan, where the virus was first detected, and the number of confirmed cases, to calculate how many people might now be infected with the #coronavirus.

name: HarvardPublicHealth
tweet: You might have heard about R0 in relation to the #coronavirus. Turns out, R0 doesn‚Äôt tell us how many people were infected by a disease or how serious the infection will be, it just gives an average number of people each person will infect.

name: HarvardPublicHealth
tweet: What is the #coronavirus (aka nCoV)? How contagious is it? And how do scientists know what they know about the virus? Harvard Chan #epidemiologist @mlipsitch and the @ccdd_hsph team break it all down for us.
